description: Lenart Kova, after assessing citywide system instability, chooses not to trigger the BCI failsafe. He authorizes Council patches to run, letting neighborhoods manage their own fixes.
Council factions deploy their own BCI patchwork through manual overrides. BCI scores and rules begin to shift unevenly across districts, creating distinct local conditions.
Residents report erratic BCI enforcement. Some areas impose sudden restrictions, others function openly. Rumors and uncertainty spread as people struggle to adapt to fractured governance.
Barter networks and informal markets appear as people cross district lines to access goods or avoid stricter zones. Civic forums reflect growing confusion and resentment toward the BCI.
A pilot zone restored with code fragments from Halden’s archives by Daria Tomenko becomes a refuge of stability. Residents migrate there, heightening debate about centralized versus local control.
